sub_topic: Calculation of the thermal expansion coefficient of a crystal
message_1: What is the thermal expansion coefficient of a sodium chloride crystal at a temperature of 293 K, knowing that its lattice parameter is 5.63 Å and its linear thermal expansion coefficient is 23.1 x 10^-6 K^-1?
message_2:
The thermal expansion coefficient of a sodium chloride (NaCl) crystal can be expressed in terms of its linear thermal expansion coefficient. The linear thermal expansion coefficient (α) is given as 23.1 x 10^-6 K^-1. 

To find the volume thermal expansion coefficient (β) of the NaCl crystal, we can use the following relationship:

β = 3α

Substituting the given value of α:

β = 3 * (23.1 x 10^-6 K^-1)
β = 69.3 x 10^-6 K^-1

So, the thermal expansion coefficient of a sodium chloride crystal at a temperature of 293 K is 69.3 x 10^-6 K^-1.
